title: 115_hr4201
content:
The "Young and Beginning Farmers Act" includes provisions for improved access to land and Department of Agriculture training and programs. It covers topics such as land trust eligibility, priority for agricultural land easements, prequalification for credit, increased farm ownership loan limits, and a report on agricultural conservation easements. The "Young and Beginning Farmers Act" includes provisions for beginning farmer coordination, transfer of Advisory Committee on Beginning Farmers and Ranchers, online customer self-service portal, training programs, individual development accounts pilot program, sale of surplus farm equipment to disadvantaged farmers, mandatory funding for farmers' market promotion, and grants for farm viability programs. TITLE I--IMPROVED ACCESS TO LAND

SEC. 101. LAND TRUST ELIGIBILITY FOR ASSISTANCE FOR AGRICULTURAL LAND EASEMENTS.

    Eligible land trusts can receive assistance to supplement the sale price of land to farmers or ranchers, while reserving an agricultural land easement for themselves. This amendment allows qualified land trusts to receive assistance under this section. SEC. 102. Priority for option to purchase at agricultural value in agricultural land easements. The Secretary shall prioritize applications for agricultural land easements that maintain agricultural viability and require subsequent land purchases at agricultural value. The Secretary of Agriculture must develop procedures by October 1, 2018, to ensure the Farm Service Agency can provide preliminary determinations to loan applicants. Additionally, there is an increase in the limitation on the amount of direct farm ownership loans. The Secretary must ensure that loans do not exceed certain limits based on the value of the security or a set amount, depending on the type of loan. The Secretary determines the farm value based on appraisals by competent appraisers. The cost inflation percentage is calculated using the Prices Paid By Farmers Index. The regional farm real estate inflation percentage is based on an index developed for the farm's region. The Secretary develops a regional farm real estate inflation index using data from the National Agricultural Statistics Service. The Secretary may establish a program for microloans with a limit of $50,000 per borrower to streamline administrative burdens. The Secretary aims to reduce administrative burdens and simplify the application process for microloans under this subsection. SEC. 105. REPORT AND ACTION PLAN ON AGRICULTURAL CONSERVATION EASEMENT PROGRAM. Congress recognizes the value of the agricultural conservation easement program in assisting beginning farmers and ranchers. The Chief of the Natural Resources Conservation Service must submit a report evaluating the program's support for acquiring farmland and a plan to address any identified shortcomings to protect farmland and help farmers access it for productive use. TITLE II--IMPROVED ACCESS TO DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE TRAINING AND PROGRAMS

SEC. 201. BEGINNING FARMER COORDINATION.

A program will be established to assign a coordinator to each State to facilitate communication between the Department of Agriculture and beginning farmers or ranchers. This program aims to increase access to apprenticeship programs, farm loan programs, and land for purchase. The coordinators may be current employees of the Department of Agriculture, and the term "State" includes all states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories. SEC. 202. TRANSFER OF ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON BEGINNING FARMERS AND RANCHERS TO JURISDICTION OF FARM SERVICE AGENCY. The Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994 is amended to transfer the Advisory Committee on Beginning Farmers and Ranchers to the jurisdiction of the Farm Service Agency. The Secretary of Agriculture is required to develop an online customer self-service portal for farmers and ranchers to access program information and complete applications. Congress emphasizes that the portal should not negatively impact those without high-speed internet. Appropriations of at least $6,000,000 are authorized for this purpose. SEC. 204. Beginning Farmer and Rancher Development Program for training, education, outreach, and technical assistance initiatives. Section 7405 of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to allow the Secretary to transfer funds for individual development accounts, with a limit of $10,000,000 per year plus administrative costs. The Secretary is restricted to using no more than 4 percent of the transferred funds for administrative costs. Mandatory funding of $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2018 is allocated from the Commodity Credit Corporation for this purpose. The section authorizes funding for individual development accounts as follows: $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2018, $30,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2019 and 2020, $40,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2021 and 2022, and $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2023 and beyond. Additionally, $30,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2018 and each subsequent year. The funds remain available until expended. SEC. 205 amends the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act to authorize $5,000,000 for the Beginning Farmer and Rancher Individual Development Accounts Pilot Program for fiscal years 2018 through 2023. SEC. 206 allows the sale of surplus farm equipment or property to socially disadvantaged farmers or ranchers, veteran farmers or ranchers, and beginning farmers or ranchers. The Administrator of General Services can sell surplus farm equipment to socially disadvantaged farmers, veteran farmers, or beginning farmers. Beginning farmers are defined as individuals or entities with less than 10 years of farming experience who actively participate in farm operations. Socially disadvantaged and veteran farmers are defined according to the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990. The terms "socially disadvantaged farmer," "veteran farmer," and "beginning farmer" are defined in the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990. TITLE III--INVESTMENT IN LOCAL AND REGIONAL FOOD SYSTEMS

SEC. 301. MANDATORY FUNDING FOR FARMERS' MARKET AND LOCAL FOOD PROMOTION PROGRAM. Amends the Farmer-to-Consumer Direct Marketing Act to allocate $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2018 to 2023.

SEC. 302. GRANTS TO SUPPORT FARM VIABILITY PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Agriculture may provide grants to support farm viability programs aimed at improving economic viability and integrity of farms through farm viability plans and providing technical assistance. $5,000,000 is authorized for grants annually from 2018 to 2023.
